text: I followed anyway. Not to be brave. Not to play hero. I just couldn’t stand the idea of her finishing everything alone while I pretended nothing was happening.
The snow was thin, but footprints were clear. She moved too fast—like missing a single second would throw off some fixed point in time.
By the time I reached the northern district, she was gone. Only a half-open iron door swayed in the wind.
Behind it, a stairway led downward. Cold air rose from below, as if someone had lit a blue lantern underground.
I didn’t descend too far. I stopped where I could see—without rushing in, without interfering. She said I would get in the way.
Low footsteps echoed below. Then the faint scrape of metal against stone. Someone laughed—not with joy, but with the certainty of someone who’d been waiting.
Alicia stepped out of the shadows, her cloak brushing the floor without wasted motion.
At the center of the sigil stood a man. His black robe thicker. The circular mark on his chest darker, almost burned into flesh. A necklace glinted at his throat.
“You finally came.” The leader raised his head, voice sick with certainty. “You always do.”
“Enough.”
Her voice was flat. All emotion pressed into the hilt of her sword.
“You want the necklace? Do you think you can take it?”
He lifted a hand. The sigil flared. The air tightened. My ears rang; I nearly lost my footing.
Alicia didn’t even blink. She stepped forward half a pace—like entering a rhythm she already knew.
“I’ve seen this before.”
Her blade flashed—a clean, merciless line. Not a flourish. Not a spectacle. Just direct intent.
The leader’s charm shattered first. The sigil cracked with a shriek. He stumbled back—but she already knew where he would retreat.
“You—!”
He tried to block. Too slow. The necklace swung at his throat, silver flickering.
She didn’t go for the kill.
“Give it.”
Her fingers hooked the chain. For a heartbeat, something like pain flashed in her eyes.
Then she pulled.
The chain snapped with a soft sound—soft enough to feel like fate tearing quietly.
The leader staggered. The sigil died. His mouth moved, but only ash-tinted breath escaped.
Alicia didn’t pursue. She clenched the necklace in her fist, as if confirming it was real.
“Finally.”
There was no triumph in her voice. Only exhaustion—like she could finally move to the next step.
I should have retreated. Instead, I froze.
She looked up. Directly at where I was hiding.
“Come out.”
“…I didn’t mean to interfere.”
“You already did.”
She said it bluntly. Then added, voice tight:
“But you’re alive. Consider that luck.”
She approached. Snow brushed from her cloak across the steps.
She tucked the necklace beneath her clothes, palm pressed over it like it might vanish.
“Back to the inn.”
“They’ll just let this go?”
“Not tonight.”
She paused, calculating probabilities in silence.
“Tomorrow I’ll clean up what’s left.”
When we emerged, the snowfall had thickened. She walked ahead. I followed. Neither of us spoke.
Only when the inn’s light appeared through the fog did her shoulders loosen slightly.
The door closed. The wind was shut outside. The hearthlight touched her face—but didn’t warm it.
“Don’t ask for details.”
“Just remember—I got what I needed.”
She turned toward the stairs. Every step light, every step hurried.
“And next time—don’t follow.”
“…Then next time, don’t go alone.”
She stopped halfway up the stairs. Didn’t turn back.
“I’ll try.”
